body:
Hi @TriMoon, thanks for the issue!

I can reproduce this, but it isn't a bug. This rule is mostly stylistic, so it reports references that appear before declarations even when those references do not cause runtime errors.

> That's why i propose an `exports` flag in [no-use-before-define#options)](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-use-before-define#options) to control the wanted behaviour.

An option to always allow references inside `export { ... }` makes sense to me :+1:

@mdjermanovic 
>I can reproduce this, but it isn't a bug. This rule is mostly stylistic, so it reports references that appear before declarations even when those references do not cause runtime errors.

If a rule **doesn't allow** something that the JavaScript engine does per default, it is a bug IMHO especially stylistic ones...
_(Emphasis on purpose.)_

It's another debate if the user should choose for it to be allowed or not :wink: 

---
@mdjermanovic 
>An option to always allow references inside export { ... } makes sense to me :+1:

Thinking about how the language handles the `export` keyword, it might even be better to change that rule to always allow it without a need/ability to change the posibility :wink: 
Perhaps in combination with a new rule fe. `exports-at-top` to choose style.

But in that case `eslint` should ofcourse still bark if the reference is never declared inside the module, eg. unable to export it. :wink:

issue.title: Rule Change: object-curly-spacing may not apply to import/export declarations

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: This change enhances an existing feature of ESLint

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
### What rule do you want to change?

object-curly-spacing

### What change to do you want to make?

Generate fewer warnings

### How do you think the change should be implemented?

A new option

### Example code

```js
import { name } from './modules/square.js';

let x = {greeting: name};
```


### What does the rule currently do for this code?

Generates a warning of one sort or another, either for { name } or for {greeting: name}, depending on which way the string option is set.

### What will the rule do after it's changed?

Not generate a warning if the object option is set to expect this combination.

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request to implement this change.

### Additional comments

The example is parts of two MDN tutorial examples, one for modules and one for object initializers. It seems like Mozilla's style guide considers braces around lists of names more like blocks and less like object destructuring (note that it also would have block-spacing: always, based on other examples).

I'm not sure what the right way to set up option(s) for this is, given that the variation between style guides seems to be in which of two rules applies to some syntax. I think just having a "moduleDeclarations": boolean option here would be sufficient, without getting into what style guide is matching instead of usual objects.

body:
The whole point of `no-use-before-define` is that you don't reference things before they're defined, whether it's for exporting or anything else.

My stylistic preference is that exports, like returns, should go at the end of the relevant section of code. Putting exports at the end obviates this issue's conflict, and since export statements are hoisted/parsed prior to evaluation, the effect is the same no matter where they're located.

@ljharb 
That is a perfectly acceptable style, just like a style with them on top of the file, it's all a **style preference** of the coders.

- Pro-argument for using them at top instead of at bottom or even middle:
  1. It provides a better overview of what `imports/exports` a modules uses, without the need to search inside the module-code.
Think about it like comments before or after some code....

Sure. That stylistic preference would be the same applied to function declarations. If that's a style you prefer, then it doesn't seem like this rule - whose entire purpose is to prevent that style - is for you.

> Sure. That stylistic preference would be the same applied to function declarations. If that's a style you prefer, then it doesn't seem like this rule - whose entire purpose is to prevent that style - is for you.

uhmmm :eyes: 
Do i smell a +1 vote for a new option to override this rule's barking in this case then?
Because a coder, like me, should be able to make use of both this rule and this style at same time...
I don’t think such an option makes sense for this particular rule, but since eslint has a ban on stylistic changes, i don’t see how any such option would qualify for addition.

@ljharb 
> I don’t think such an option makes sense for this particular rule, but since eslint has a ban on stylistic changes, i don’t see how any such option would qualify for addition.


ahhh so `eslint` just likes to put its head in ground when it comes to es6+ features? (I doubt that)
There are more issues related to  `import/export` statements as far as i could see, which require stylistic changes/adding to properly support the technological advancements.

It's disappointing to read such a reaction from a (sponsor) contributor...

It would be another thing if you were against changing this rule in favor of adding a new one, in which case im open to discuss possibilities,
But such a hard rejecting statement is well...disappointing.

@TriMoon ljharb is referring to our [policies about stylistic rules](https://github.com/eslint/eslint#stylistic-rule-updates).

@ljharb this rule was originally purely stylistic. As of es6, it can also be used to prevent TDZ errors, and the [documentation](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-use-before-define) for this rule does mention TDZ as one of the rationales for using the rule. Since this rule can be used for different purposes, I'm supportive of an option to disable a stylistic-only exports check so that the rule can be configured to only warn about statically determinable TDZ errors.

> I'm supportive of an option to disable a stylistic-only exports check so that the rule can be configured to only warn about statically determinable TDZ errors.

Makes sense to me 👍
Oops! It looks like we lost track of this issue. What do we want to do here? This issue will auto-close in 7 days without an update.
